title: The Dangers of Safety
summary: Explores the unexpected trade-offs when society prioritizes safety, with examples ranging from child-proofing to car seats.
utterances: Sometimes, interventions bring surprising new risks.
Do we underestimate the cost of feeling safe?
Not all regulations make things safer in practice.
transcript: Steven Levitt and Stephen Dubner talk to economists and psychologists about real-world effects of safety laws, why they work, and when they backfire.

title: The Power of Incentives
summary: Shows how incentives shape choices in education, business, and daily life, sometimes in counterintuitive ways.
utterances: People respond to incentives—we just don’t always predict how.
How much does money motivate teachers or criminals?
Incentives can be both the problem and solution.
transcript: Economists and behavioral scientists share classic and surprising examples of incentives at work.

title: Bad Medicine, Part 1: The Story of 98.6
summary: Questions the legitimacy of medical benchmarks like a 'normal' body temperature and challenges what we think we know about health standards.
utterances: Why is 98.6°F the standard—and is it accurate?
Medical guidelines are less universal than they seem.
History and science aren’t always in sync.
transcript: Medical historians and clinicians discuss how benchmarks are created and how medical myths persist.

title: Bad Medicine, Part 2: Concussion Inc.
summary: Investigates the science, business, and controversy around concussions in football, and why solutions are so hard to implement.
utterances: The NFL’s relationship to science is more complex than admitted.
Concussion science is evolving fast.
Injury tracking has changed public health debates.
transcript: Talks with sports economists, doctors, and league officials on how incentives warped the safety conversation.

title: Why We Ignore Experts
summary: Examines why people distrust expertise, from weather forecasts to financial advice, and who gets listened to in a crisis.
utterances: Why do we believe gut instincts over hard data?
Distrust of experts is as old as expertise itself.
Public trust moves in cycles.
transcript: Reflects on examples from government and business—why sometimes crowds get it wrong, but sometimes they beat the experts.

title: Are We Ready for Autonomous Cars?
summary: Looks at the technology, ethics, and challenges of driverless cars and what they'll mean for the future of transportation.
utterances: Self-driving cars already exist in limited ways.
The hardest part may be public trust, not technology.
Insurance, law, and behavior have to evolve too.
transcript: Features insights from engineers, urban planners, and ethicists forecasting the next steps for autonomous vehicles.

title: The Upside of Quitting
summary: Reframes quitting as a rational choice, using stories from business, sports, and love lives.
utterances: Winners sometimes quit first.
Stick-to-it-iveness isn’t always the smartest path.
Sunk costs cloud our judgment.
transcript: Discussion with behavioral economists reveals why most of us hang on too long to bad investments and failing strategies.

title: The No-Tipping Point
summary: Explores why some restaurants drop tipping, the psychology behind tips, and unexpected results of changing payment systems.
utterances: No-tipping restaurants are on the rise.
Cultural expectations play a huge role.
The debate over pay fairness isn’t over.
transcript: Restaurateurs, economists, and servers share data and anecdotes about pay equity and customer satisfaction.

title: How to Think About Crime
summary: Steven Levitt and Steven Dubner confront the real numbers behind crime, policing, and prevention—and why intuition often fails.
utterances: Crime stats don’t always match perceptions.
Broken windows theory has surprising limits.
Prevention doesn’t always mean punishment.
transcript: Policymakers and criminologists explain what actually lowers crime rates and what does not.

title: How Is a Bad Radio Station Like Our Public-School System?
summary: Draws odd but revealing parallels between failing public schools and struggling radio stations, focusing on incentives and accountability.
utterances: Measuring outcomes isn’t always popular.
Accountability is tricky in both schools and media.
Making improvements often means making enemies.
transcript: Education reformers and radio executives share lessons about feedback, metrics, and institutional change.

title: The Hidden Side of Everything
summary: Introduces the idea that almost any part of daily life can be understood—and improved—through data and economic thinking.
utterances: Economics explains more than just money.
Hidden connections are everywhere.
Asking new questions reveals hidden solutions.
transcript: Levitt and Dubner mix classic stories and new examples to show how their approach uncovers what’s broken and why.

title: Why Do We Really Follow the News?
summary: Looks at the psychology and incentives behind news consumption, selective attention, and why outrage sells.
utterances: Fear and anxiety shape the news we seek.
Headlines are behavioral cues.
Fake news is as old as news itself.
transcript: Journalists and psychologists unpack how habits and business models shape the world’s information diet.

title: Is College Really Worth It?
summary: Dissects the real costs and benefits of higher education—economically, personally, and for society.
utterances: Degree costs are higher than ever.
What skills are worth the tuition?
Education pays—but only for some.
transcript: Economists, students, and business leaders debate what return on investment college offers in the modern world.

title: What Makes a Donor?
summary: Surveys the economics and psychology of giving—why some donate money, time, or even organs, and how incentives matter.
utterances: Altruism isn’t always selfless.
Small incentives change donor behavior.
Social pressure is powerful, for good and bad.
transcript: Features data on charitable giving, organ donation, and the surprising impact of recognition or gifts.

title: How to Save a Life
summary: Explores how hospitals, governments, and charities approach saving lives, and debates what actually works best.
utterances: Zero harm is seldom possible, but big gains are.
Simple interventions can lead to huge results.
Resource allocation means tough ethical choices.
transcript: Doctors and public policy experts weigh evidence on health strategies, rules and randomness in survival odds.

title: Why Are So Many People Moving to Cities?
summary: Looks at the economic and social factors driving historic urbanization, and what cities must do to thrive.
utterances: City living offers both opportunity and risk.
Urbanization is speeding up worldwide.
Infrastructure shapes how cities grow and prosper.
transcript: Mayors, urban economists, and planners debate the pros and cons of city expansion, density, and changing values.

title: The Science of Shopping
summary: Unpacks why and how we shop—the role of design, psychology, and nudges in influencing spending.
utterances: Shopping patterns are engineered as much as chosen.
Retailers exploit habits to drive sales.
Discounts can backfire, increasing costs.
transcript: Retail experts, store owners, and behavioral scientists discuss how mental shortcuts lead to spending.

title: Good Fences, Bad Neighbors
summary: Examines the truth behind property lines, housing policy, and how neighborhoods mix or clash.
utterances: Fences shape opportunity as much as ownership.
Integrated neighborhoods transform lives—and politics.
Gentrification pits progress against displacement.
transcript: Sociologists, city officials, and residents share stories of community, conflict, and policy reform.

title: When Is a Bribe a Bargain?
summary: Considers the economic, ethical, and cultural sides of bribery—from local kickbacks to global corruption.
utterances: Not all gifts are bribes—but lines get blurry.
Law and morality don’t always line up.
Corruption affects rich and poor alike.
transcript: Legal scholars, businesspeople, and citizens around the world discuss why bribery persists and how it shifts markets.

title: The Downside of Good Intentions
summary: Explores how well-meaning actions can create harmful side effects, from charitable giving to overzealous policies.
utterances: Intentions alone rarely guarantee good results.
Unintended consequences are everywhere.
Learning means admitting and correcting mistakes.
transcript: Nonprofit leaders, entrepreneurs, and economists unravel how good deeds can go astray and what to do about it.
